verses.text: Have mercy on me, O God, according to your steadfast love; according to the greatness of your compassion blot out my transgressions.
verses.comment: David appeals to the unfailing love of God. The reference to 'blot out' evokes the idea of God erasing sins—paralleling concepts of divine forgiveness seen in Isaiah 43:25. Early Christian writers spiritually connected these words with sacramental forgiveness and interior conversion.

verses.text: Wash me thoroughly from my guilt, and cleanse me from my sin.
verses.comment: The imagery of washing and cleansing is strong here, foretelling spiritual purification found in the New Testament (Titus 3:5; John 13:8). The concept anticipates the idea of spiritual regeneration through water and the Spirit.

verses.text: For I know my transgressions, and my sin is always before me.
verses.comment: Acknowledging sin is the first step toward healing. David's penitence is a model for personal confession, central for restoration to God.

verses.text: Against you, you alone, have I sinned, and done what is evil in your sight, so that you are proven right when you speak and are justified when you judge.
verses.comment: Sin is ultimately an offense against God. Paul quotes this verse in Romans 3:4 to show God's justice. The spiritual meaning points to the seriousness of sin and the necessity of contrition.

verses.text: Look, I was brought forth in iniquity, and in sin my mother conceived me.
verses.comment: This verse emphasizes the doctrine of original sin—humanity's inherited fallen state. The spiritual tradition sees in this a call for supernatural aid to overcome our innate weakness.

verses.text: Behold, you desire truth in the inward being; and in the secret heart you teach me wisdom.
verses.comment: God desires inner honesty, not just outward compliance. The spiritual meaning suggests that grace forms the heart, teaching wisdom and true repentance from within.

verses.text: Purify me with hyssop, and I shall be clean; wash me, and I shall be whiter than snow.
verses.comment: Hyssop was used for ritual cleansing in the Law (see Leviticus). Here, it symbolizes an interior cleansing, anticipated in Christian sacramental thought, especially regarding rites of purification and forgiveness.

verses.text: Let me hear joy and gladness; let the bones you have broken rejoice.
verses.comment: The image of broken bones represents the pain of repentance, but also the future joy of forgiveness. The spiritual sense points to the restoration that follows true contrition.

verses.text: Hide your face from my sins, and blot out all my iniquities.
verses.comment: David earnestly asks God to turn away from his sins—a full acquittal. This language echoes how complete forgiveness is, not merely ignoring but truly eliminating the sin.

verses.text: Create in me a pure heart, O God, and renew a steadfast spirit within me.
verses.comment: David recognizes only God can transform the human heart. Christian tradition links this with spiritual rebirth (Ezekiel 36:26, John 3:5).

verses.text: Do not cast me away from your presence, and do not take your Holy Spirit from me.
verses.comment: This verse directly appeals to the gift and presence of the Holy Spirit, anticipated here and fulfilled more fully at Pentecost (Acts 2). God’s indwelling Spirit empowers steadfastness and holiness.

verses.text: Restore to me the joy of your salvation, and uphold me with a willing spirit.
verses.comment: Joy is the fruit of restored relationship with God. The willing spirit refers to the grace to remain faithful, indicating that both forgiveness and perseverance are God's gifts.

verses.text: Then I will teach transgressors your ways, and sinners will return to you.
verses.comment: Repentance and forgiveness lead to evangelization; David wants to guide others to repentance. Forgiven sinners can best witness the mercy of God, fulfilling Christ’s call to make disciples (Matt. 28:19).

verses.text: Deliver me from bloodguiltiness, O God, the God of my salvation, and my tongue will sing aloud of your deliverance.
verses.comment: Bloodguilt recalls David's sin concerning Uriah (2 Samuel 12). He desires not only forgiveness but public worship—praise for God’s saving work.

verses.text: O Lord, open my lips, and my mouth will declare your praise.
verses.comment: Worship is a response to God’s initiative. God empowers true worship—one can see this fulfilled in the praise offered in Christian liturgy and public witness.

verses.text: For you do not delight in sacrifice, or I would give it; you do not take pleasure in burnt offerings.
verses.comment: External sacrifices are empty without inner repentance. The prophets and Christ himself echo the need for mercy and interior conversion (Matthew 9:13).

verses.text: The sacrifices of God are a broken spirit; a broken and contrite heart, O God, you will not despise.
verses.comment: True sacrifice is inward—heartfelt repentance. This is foundational in the spiritual tradition: contrition opens the door to God’s mercy in a unique and powerful way.

verses.text: Do good in your good pleasure to Zion; build up the walls of Jerusalem.
verses.comment: David’s personal prayer extends to the whole people of God. Spiritually, this verse foreshadows the corporate nature of worship, where God’s favor is sought for the community.

verses.text: Then you will delight in right sacrifices, in offerings and whole burnt offerings; then bulls will be offered on your altar.
verses.comment: God desires sincere worship, not mere ritual. Once the heart is made right, external worship pleases God, highlighting the seamless connection between interior conversion and public worship—anticipating the union of heart and ritual in the new covenant.
